Christian thoughtfully leads the reader though a variety of themes and topics pertaining to the human condition and considers the struggles and barriers computer scientists and AI leaders have faced in trying to simulate or replicate the ineffable attributes of mankind. He does so in a very balanced way though, never slamming the AI community or getting lost in a frenzied Orwellian tone. The themes consisted of things like conversation, identity, compression, innovation, memory, routine, culture, and relationships. I listened to this book, which I think added to my enjoyment of it because it is very poetical. I think some of the imagery would have been lost to me in reading it, and some of the thoughts provoked might have been lost in the cognitive load of pulling meaning from written text. Being poetical, this book was a bit hard to follow in terms of overall point or theme. I didn't mind it that much, but as mentioned above I think I would have struggled with it a bit more if I had read it instead of listened to it. However, one should really spend time with this book. It is by definition and subject more about spending time with the thing than getting through it. I loved how it expanded my thinking about what it means to be a human, and what the future of machines might be like. Indeed, what the future of THINKING ABOUT machines might be like! Be ready for some fascinating bits of thinking around things like programmed chess, autocorrect, the phrases "um" and "ah" in language, and the comparison of lossless compression to our daily lived experience. This is a fascinating read and offers increasingly more important food for thought in our technology saturated world.

What makes us distinctly human? That is the question at the center of this book. Avoiding pretension and useless vagaries, Christian offers up a series of thoughtful meditations in answer, which orient around the major themes of the human capacity for spontaneity, surprise, and artistic creativity. What I especially enjoyed and appreciated about this book were Christian's ability and commitment to see the computer less as a threat and more as an unrelenting question about what we want to stake our humanity on. Framed in such a way, the computer is like a good conversational partner that helps us to learn more about ourselves through the conversation. At different points while reading, I thought that Christian moved too quickly from one thought to the next and did not linger to sustain some thoughts enough. But then I realized that this may be an intentional and possibly brilliant maneuver on Christian's part. That is, this book reads less like a slow and steady argument from beginning to end and more like one of those wandering and deep conversations that you have at 3AM in the morning with a good friend that is well read. Christian writes the book as though it is a conversation, whereby he moves quickly from one topic to the next, in much the way that conversations do. Fortunately, Christian is well read and he is sure to surprise and enlighten his readers with new and thoughtful connections and metaphors. And therein lies the brilliance. Christian exemplifies in his writing the kind of spontaneity, opportunities for surprise, and creativity that he is otherwise pointing to as the distinctly human. That is, Christian does not merely describe authentic humanity, he also strives to evidence it in his own writing about the subject. This is an accessible and enjoyable book that I would recommend to a wide reading audience.

I have a bad habit: I often get seduced by books with clever or funny titles, buying them without really researching them (the primary reason I own The Right to Arm Bears).It is possible, however, that I would have purchased this book even after a little research. After all, I'm a software developer and AI is a fascinating topic for me. And that's what I expected this book to be about.But it's not. It's 271 pages of Christian rambling on about whatever topic strikes his fancy. The narrative is framed by him taking part in the 2009 Loebner prize as a "confederate", a human who must (hopefully) convince a judge, in five minutes and via nothing but a chat program, that they are indeed a human and not an AI.I was hoping for a discussion of the various techniques used by the AI competitors. While there were brief excursions into computer science, they were not in any depth.The bulk of the book was taken up by Christian arguing about how conversation is something that truly defines a human as a human, and computers may never master it. An old, tired argument, and one that was made about chess up until fifteen years ago. Then Deep Blue came along and the goalposts of AI shifted - "chess is a simple matter of computation, a computer can be good at it without any real intelligence". Christian talks at some length about this in his book, but he seems completely oblivious to the irony of him making exactly the same arguments about conversation.If you can get past the philosophical navel-gazing (something I barely managed to do in spots), there are definitely parts of this book that are really interesting. It touches on a huge number of subjects, from computer science to information theory to literature to linguistics.

If you are a fan of philosophical discussion and debate, this is a great book in entertaining the idea of what it means to be a human. If non-fiction and theory based ideas are not your cup of tea, you'll probably hate this one. I did find it enjoyable, although I disagreed with a few parts (particularly the author's idea of compression and literature, but I also believe the finer points of a book are in the sentences that make up the story...not just the summary of the story itself). What I did find lacking was the resolution of the contest. The Turing test, pitting humans and computers against a panel of judges, in which the judges must guess which is human and which is a computer. Then, the "most human computer" gets a prize, and ironically, the "most human human" also gets an honorable prize. While reading a bit of the transcripts of the contest, I found myself sucked in...but a full transcript of the exchange is never provided. Furthermore, once the winner of the most human human prize is announced there is...well, nothing. "You win, here ya go, on to the next chapter" is hardly a satisfying finish to a long book questioning the very essence of what makes a human centered around this very contest (it's like watching Rocky, but when the fight starts, it jumps right to the announcement of Apollo winning the decision, without watching the fight at all. But, those were the only drawbacks. The author uses human, layman's terms, and a bit of scientific and philosophic research to venture through the various characteristics of what makes a human a human. Thought, emotion, decision making process, and even interaction with other humans (and machines) are all fleshed out and sometimes even examined at microscopic levels to the point of causing the reader to also question their own definition of what makes a human.

Amazingly dense but very readable and a lot of funOstensibly the book is about Brian Christian’s adventure preparing for and playing as a human “confederate” in the 2009 annual Loebner Prize contest. This is the competition in which AI enthusiasts use the Turning test to see which computers are the best at fooling human judges into thinking they are human. Christian sits at a remote computer and tries to convince the judges that he is a human and not just a bot pretending to be human. If he succeeds and he is the best of the humans he will win the “Most Human Human” award.I think that after reading this book that Christian is indeed a very human human. He is clever, creative, curious to an almost amazing degree and is social; but whether he is the most human human will be in considerable doubt even if he wins the award. (No spoilers here!) The reason is simple: the Turing test tells us nothing about Christian physically and very little about him emotionally. But more than that the Turing test (and this book) is really more—much more—about language than it is about what it means to be alive (as in the subtitle of the book).Christian is an expert on language—I should say languages since he is a computer geek as well as a teacher of poetry. He knows code and he knows Shakespeare. And Christian is also very smart and very knowledgeable as you’ll discover by reading this book. So (of course!) he can’t be the most human human. Alas.Christian is also a very good writer. His writing style is loud, bold, adventuresome and full of “Look mom, I’m writing” flourishes. There are asides aplenty and oodles of arcane factoids sprinkled everywhere. A poet writes in a nonlinear fashion using poetic devices such as sound and rhythm to enhance meaning. Christian writes like a poet but instead of relying on familiar poetic devices to achieve nonlinear communication he uses ideas and facts from a large variety of human disciplines to achieve the dense feel this book has. Too much information (TMI) is not something that Christian fears!Okay, let’s go back to the book’s title. Notice that the first “human” is an adjective while the second one is a noun. MS Word’s grammar and spell checker doesn’t understand the distinction which is why the second “human” is underlined in red in my text file. But a computer program that does recognize the difference in usage would not see the second “human” as an error. People notice the distinction without thinking about it and without even being aware that one word is an adjective and the other a noun. And that in a nutshell is what the competition is all about: knowing how humans use and understand language.Here’s an example of something similar from the concluding chapter. It’s a headline in which Christian changes the word “offensive” from the intended noun form into an adjective with amusing consequences: “UK Minister’s Charm Offensive.” (p. 268)What makes this book so very interesting is how Christian goes about trying to solve the problem of how to appear human over a computer terminal. What is it that makes us uniquely human, and what can we type to make it clear that we are not a computer program? Since the evidence that the judges would get would be in the form of language—words and symbols typed from a keyboard—Christian’s prep involved a deep study of language. He looked at pauses in speech and seemingly non-meaningful utterances like “um” and “uh” to see what they really conveyed. He found that some sounds meant the speaker wanted to interrupt, or to continue speaking without being interrupted. He called some of this “barging in,” and found that is what humans do. Do chatbots trying to imitate humans know enough to barge in? And then there is the “body language” component of human communication. According to the “7-38-55” rule advanced by UCLA psych prof Albert Mehrabian, “55 percent of what you convey when you speak comes from your body language, 38 percent from your tone of voice, and a paltry 7 percent from the words you choose.” (p. 174) How might Christian include some body language in his effort to convince the judge that he is human? He can’t so he is stuck with the paltry seven percent to work with.And then there is this way of looking at the Turning test: it’s a lie-detector test. The computer is lying and so the judge has to expose the lies. And the “confederate” has to show the judge that he is not lying.And then there are “holds” in conversations, words, phrases, ideas that come up in conversations that encourage the other speaker to reply or ask a relevant question or maybe to change the subject. (Called “holds” from the holds in rock climbing.) How the remote reacts to holds may help the judge know if the remote is a computer or a human. Using holds is distinct from “streamlining” in which the speaker expresses something in a generic and/or nonspecific way, such as saying “I went home” instead of “I bicycled home.” There’s no hold in the first statement. The word “bicycled” is the hold in the second. A human might respond with a question about bicycling. (A smart bot might as well.)Sometimes Christian just likes to show off—and he does it well. For example he makes the point that some surnames come from occupations, such as “Cook,” “Baker,” “Smith”—but no! He doesn’t use such obvious examples. Instead he gives us “Fletchers,” “Coopers,” and “Sawyers,” and tells us that Fletchers made arrows, Coopers made barrels and Sawyers cut wood. He goes on to recall that Chris Moneymaker won some serious coin playing poker and that Usain Bolt can run like lightening while informing us that these serendipitous examples are called “aptronyms.” (pp. 187-188)Finally I want to mention the “Shannon Game” (after Claude Shannon, founder of information theory). The way it works is you try to guess the next letter or space in a sentence—letter not word. Your ability to do so relates to the amount of entropy in the letters. High entropy letters are usually the less-used letters, less predictable and therefore seemingly more random. If the sentence begins “The mastermind failed...” the letters after the first “T” are easy to guess and have low entropy since “the” is one of the most common words in the language. But the “f” has high entropy because it is hard to guess since the “mastermind” could be doing, saying, thinking, or being most anything.I was going to call this a “cute book on a cute subject” but after reading it I discovered that it is much deeper than that. Insofar as possessing language is the essence of what distinguishes us from other animals (and it is to a large extent), Christian’s discoveries and his experiences here are profound.—Dennis Littrell, author of “The World Is Not as We Think It Is”

The content of this book was great. The author, however, comes across as someone with a very inflated opinion of his own knowledge, but who relies on myriad quotes to make any of his points. In good writing, I feel quoting should be used as little as possible, and only in support of something you have already put into words yourself. At one point Christian ironically quotes Dali - "The first man to compare the cheeks of a young woman to a rose was obviously a poet; the first to repeat it was possibly an idiot." to make the point that a poetry bot spewing out tired trope and worn-out metaphors is missing the key ingredient of creativity and novel expression that makes human poetry and writing so special. His quote is supposed to teach us (the readers) a lesson, but I think he needs to take a harder look at that himself. I don't mean to be too harsh here, which I probably have been. I did, on balance, enjoy reading 'The Most Human Human'. I just felt that Christian's arrogance and, at times, condescension, was really distracting from what was often fascinating subject matter, and this was much to the book's detriment. His story is of his learning curve ahead of the competition for the Loebner Prize - a curve copied by the reader as they progress through the book - and in my opinion it would have been nicer if he had been someone for the reader to identify with a little more during that progression.On the whole, as a linguist and someone with a little bit of knowledge of and interest in computer science, this book provided me with plenty of daydreaming material, and some interesting conversational tidbits. It's not life-changing, but it's decent commuter reading that gives you something to chat about over coffee.

I really love this book. The mix of philosophy and artificial intelligence is interesting throughout. I'm only part of the way through, but I hope he ties it all together in the end. It is sort of all over the place. Parts of this have really made me think. The author researched and worked to participate in the Turing Test - where humans and computers both hold conversations with the judges and try to convince them they are the human. The author succeeds by being unpredictable, and by using humor, among other things. Here's another review that I don't want to forget.It's actually hard to describe this book because it covers so many areas. This makes sense, as Christian is basically trying to define what it means to be human, which is a rather complex question to answer. He has background in a lot of different areas (poetry, philosophy, computers) and this comes out in the writing--he is able to be compelling and technical, poetic and funny, and above all, clear. Despite jumping around to cover almost any subject you can think of while ostensibly answering the question "What makes us human, and can computers ever capture that quality?" it never feel unfocused--although it never exactly answers the question. Very satisfying and enjoyable, and I particularly liked the many footnotes that added even more tangential trivia tidbits to the book.What I noticed about this book is that if you pay attention to the main theme of the book--how one might convince someone else that you are human while conversing with them--he rather subtly follows all his own advice while writing this book

"You can't simply 'get to know' a person without, to some degree, changing them-and without, to some degree, becoming them.""Like most conversations and most chess games, we all start off the same and we all end up the same, with a brief moment of difference in between. Fertilization to fertilizer. Ashes to ashes. And we spark across the gap."There are books you love and then there are books you love so much that you immediately think of friends to buy them for. I'm definitely putting this on my Christmas 'to buy' list. Christian writes well and accessibly about what artificial intelligence research, and its intersection with philosophy, tells us about being human. It's a rare gift to write engagingly about a complex topic and toe the line between oversimplification and excessive detail.Most importantly, this book explained things about myself. Why do I feel more connected to certain friends even if I 'like' all of my friends equally? (See: Getting Out of Book) Why do I feel the need to obsessively proofread every email I send to try and guess how it might come across?Christian takes us through a loosely connected tour of artificial intelligence and philosophy, stopping along the way to give us historical insight into how the 'seat of the soul' has changed over the past few thousand years. And then the linguistic theory in the final chapter was interesting, especially when applying ideas like entropy and irreducibility to prose and language. In short, it's a great multifaceted tour of what it means to be human. I should probably go ahead and re-read it!And beyond that, what it means to be me.

The AI community meets together to assess the "human-ness" of the latest and greatest in computer technology. The best computer is awarded "the Most Human Computer" award. And, in addition, there is a small additional contest for "the Most Human Human."  Brian Christian decides to compete for "the Most Human Human." He is an intriguing person who has degrees in computer technology, philosophy, and poetry. (That is such an odd combination of degrees that I feel led to repeat it again: He is an intriguing person who has degrees in computer technology, philosophy, and poetry.)  Christian thinks about what it means to be humaan in the world in which we live, the world that was, and the world that is to come. I had many ah-ha moments while reading this book: Christian relates a story about an author who attempts to outsource his customer service department only to be besieged by new reps calling to ask how to solve problems. In desperation, the author finally sends the reps an e-mail that says, "Don't ask me for permission. Do what you think is right." Suddenly, the calls to the author cease and customer service ratings rapidly improve. "Micromanagement; the kaizen-less assembly line; the overstandardization of brittle procedures and protocols...these problems are precisely the same problem, and pose precisely the same danger, as does AI. In all four cases, a robot will be doing your job. The only difference is that in the first three, the robot will be you." "...kids are much quicker studies at learning to ski because they are not afraid to fall. Fail and recover."

3.8 stars (not quite 4 but I'm willing to round up)Christian provides a nice description through his journey to try to discover what it really means to be human (the goal of which is to win the Most Human Human award at the annual Turing test). The answer he comes up with is that of grounded spontaneity (TM): humans can be spontaneous in their actions, but this spontaneity is not randomness (which has no meaning and no connection to previous states). It is, rather, creating a fork on the path that one is traveling along. The book (essentially) explores this one idea from several different angles, from information theory and compression algorithms to customer service reps following a set script to pick-up artists. The most successful metaphor was his discussion of chess. Discussing how the game is played, he notes that a chess game really only gets interesting in the middle (out of the opening moves and before falling into the end game). This is called "getting out of book", where the book is common knowledge about what you are supposed to do to open the game and, when the game is coming close, how you are supposed to play in order to finish off your opponent. "Getting out of book" is where the game is more spontaneous, free-flowing, and less likely to be, in some sense, determined. Your mileage may vary with this book. I found most of it interesting. The organization was clunky in certain chapters and there were too many subsections (especially since the transitions between many subsections was abrupt). If you are interested in a fun (and relatively light) treatment of what it means to be human, you will enjoy this.

"The word games Scattergories and Boggle are played differently but scored the same way. Players, each with a list of words they've come up with, compare lists and cross off every word that appears on more than one list. The player with the most words remaining on her sheet wins. I've always fancied this a rather cruel way of keeping score. Imagine a player who comes up with four words, and each of her four opponents only comes up with one of them. The round is a draw, but it hardly feels like one....As the line of human uniqueness pulls back ever more, we put the eggs of our identity into fewer and fewer baskets; then the computer comes along and takes that final basket, crosses off that final word. And we realize that uniqueness, per se, never had anything to do with it. The ramparts we built to keep other species and other mechanisms out also kept us in. In breaking down that last door, computers have let us out. And back into the light.

Who would have imagined that the computer's earliest achievements would be in the domain of logical analysis, a capacity held to be what made us most different from everything on the planet? That it could drive a car and guide a missile before it could ride a bike? That it could make plausible preludes in the style of Bach before it could make plausible small talk? That it could translate before it could paraphrase? That it could spin half-plausible postmodern theory essays before it could be shown a chair and say, as any toddler can, "chair"? We forget what the impressive things are. Computers are reminding us."

The development of Artificial Intelligence is big news - with competing camps worried about the advent of the "singularity" (when machines become smarter than us), and others concerned about its impact on jobs and skills. I am rather relaxed - the ability of AI to support tasks outside of a narrowly defined field is over hyped, and the opportunity it gives to enhance rather than enslave human life carries much promise. This book is concerned with the differences between human and machine intelligence. Brian Christian took part in the Turing Test as part of the Loebner Contest in Brighton several years ago. In the test, devised by and named after the sainted Alan, humans converse with disembodied others using messaging, trying to determine if they are talking to a human or a machine. Christian was voted "The Most Human Human" in that year's particular set of tests.The book rather rambles, however it makes a good fist at exploring the human mind's phenomenal abilities at reasoning, linguistics, and even information compression techniques. It covers art, philosophy, science and interesting diversions on topics like chess playing. It's conclusions rather back up my own hypothesis - we have little to fear from computer intelligence, the bigger problem will be to try and ensure we don't ask AI to run before it can even make toddler steps. AI can successfully play GO or Chess, but it remains hopeless at understanding and summarizing the emotions behind even the simplest of children's stories. Christian celebrates and clearly provides evidence for our awesome abilities, and by comparison shows how dumb machines really are.

What I love about this book is the idea that machines could potentially make us more human, forcing us to reexamine the standards we hold for ourselves. Basically, I found this book in the 'new nonfiction' section of the library, and I was immediately intrigued by the title.when the read the first section, about the Turing test, which is a competition for AI program designers where judges talk via chat with a computer and a human and try to tell which one is which. The computer program that best simulates humans is awarded 'the most human computer' award. The human that best convinces judges that they are human is awarded 'the most human human' award. Brian Christian spends the book exploring how humans talk, interact, and what makes us human. I love how he kind of argues with himself, refutes his own arguments. However, i felt like the supersciencey, partsofbraindothisandthat parts were a bit tedious. Furthermore, since it's nonfiction, it was a bit hard to read all in one sitting. I kept reading, hoping to get a complete log of HIS conversations with the judges, since he included so many other people's, but all we got was a small story and then 'oh I won the most human human award!' that was disappointing. The book is funny though, which is hard to do in nonfiction, and I love the hopeful message it ends ~ even if someday, a computer won the Turing test, it would just end the Turing test, not humanity, which can reinvent itself continuously. He never did tell us how to be human best, did he

The central premise of the book is excellent and thought provoking: Maybe the fact that machines are starting to look more human is a sign that a) Yes, technology is improving, but b) Maybe humans are getting worse at being human. Hidden behind this question is to what degree we begin to act more like machines the more we interact with them. With interactions between cultures, a least something gets exchanged from one side to the other. Maybe the same thing happens when we interact with machines.My problem with the book is that it rambled and wandered into other questions. Certainly these were related questions, like the nature of the soul, language, and so on, but those parts I found much less interesting. There were times when I felt Christian was reaching to turn what would have been a great 25 page article into a book.Still, his basic point about the general dumbing down of our communication and the staged responses that dominate much of our discourse holds true.The book did raise another question that near as I can tell (I did skip some sections) the author did not deal with. Why are some so bent on proving that machines are 'human?' Is it- Done by some in a vacuum, all for the sake of the experiment itself, or- Done because ultimately this will help us discover what it means to be human after all, or- Done because some hate the idea of humanity and secretly, even if unconsciously, seek to abolish it.I feel like there is an excellent documentary in the making somewhere there.

I don’t necessarily hate starting a conversation with “Hello, how are you?” What I hate is that you, or whomever I’m talking to, will probably respond “Fine” or “Good,” even when you might not be. It’s such a neutral, standard response that it’s lost all meaning. A computer is great at these types of seemingly scripted exchanges, as Brian Christian quickly learns when preparing for the 2009 Turing Test, where judges engage in short instant-message conversations and have to decide whether they’re chatting with a computer or a human. “Pleasantries are low entropy, biased so far that they stop being an earnest inquiry and become ritual. Ritual has its virtues, of course, and I don’t quibble with them in the slightest. But if we really want to start fathoming someone, we need to get them speaking in sentences we can’t finish.” This is just one of many poignant observations Christian makes about the ways humans and computers differ (or, at times, operate similarly) as he tries to figure out how to ensure the judges will deem him human so he can win the Turing Test’s “Most Human Human” award. I don’t want to spoil whether he is in fact the most human human of 2009, but I can tell you he’s at least a very intelligent and witty one, and his narration is engaging even when he’s reading transcripts of instant message conversations. Whether you’re interested in machines or art, and especially why machines can’t make art on their own, there are plenty of soul-searching passages here for everyone.

How to ace the Turing Test.A How-To manual of how to converse like a human being.By looking at recent research in AI and cognitive psychology, Christian tries to understand what it means to be a human.He acted as the human 'decoy' or confederate on the 2009 Loebner Prize competition, where 'judges' communicate with unknown entities over a text-only interface, and have to judge the 'humanness' of their interlocutor. Each year the 'most human computer' is crowned as the winner, but Christian's goal was a different one: Each year the 'most human human', i.e. the one that gets the highest marks on 'humanness' by the judges, is also determined, and this was the prize that Christian was aiming for. His preparation for the competition here serves as a backdrop for a study of what it entails to behave like a human - and what the difference is between this and /being/ a human.It is a very interesting discussion of what makes a discussion interesting, which involves experts and expertise from many walks of life - from pick-up artists to poets to programmers. Interspersed in the narrative of the Loebner Prize are chapters on information theory, poetry and dating that could have been knitted together more tightly.The book starts with an eyebrow-raising factoid - that Claude Shannon (an early pioneer in information theory) married a computer¹. Christian misses a trick by not ending the book by looking at what it would mean for a (modern-day) computer to be able to marry.¹which in those days of course was a (human) job description, not a machine.

Review notes:-Brian Christian really fleshes out the central anecdote, his participation as a convince-you-I'm-human "confederate" vs. AI chat-bots at the Loebner Prize (a Turing Test challenge), framing the contest with asides in psychology, philosophy of mind, physics, logic and computing, games, communication, language and linguistics, and other topics that illustrate the complexity of interaction on display here. Broadly insightful and rarely overwrought.-Author's background in science writing and philosophy plus his MFA in Poetry correspond well to the fluidity with which he moves between tangential topics while keeping sight of the central theme. The book revolves around communication, in particular the written word since text is the format for the Turing Test undertaken, and Brian Christian's well-written prose shows off the fact that he studied and contemplated the topic well in preparation for his Loebner Prize contest and vie for the Most Human Human.-Topically very similar to the likewise recently published book by James Gleick, The Information: A History, A Theory, A Flood.

I enjoyed this book. However, reading the full-length version did not add much to my appreciation of the subject compared to just reading The Atlantic magazine article ("Mind vs. Machine", March 2011) that summarized author Brian Christian's participation as a human confederate competing against chat bots in the 2009 Turing Test.Christian devoted a lot of time to discussing chess, drawing an analogy between chess matches and conversations - both usually rely on customary openings (greetings) and closings (goodbyes) drawn from a standard set of options, and in only some instances do they develop a substantial "off book" middle section in which more interesting and unpredictable things happen. He observed that chat bots and computerized chess models strove to minimize the "off book" portion because they performed better in more familiar territory. As someone who has not studied chess, I thought Christian's point was well taken but found this section of the book overly long.Descriptions of the Turing Test proceedings and chat transcripts from previous competitions were more interesting, by turns amusing and ironic. Overall, this was a good read. The book made some important philosophical concepts about the nature of humanity more accessible and provided a thoughtful discussion of artificial intelligence and which of humans' claims to uniqueness are most defensible and/or valuable.

This is really maybe a 3.5. What kind of book would you expect from a Brown graduate with a double major in computer science & philosophy and a master's degree in poetry? Probably something like The Most Human Human. Christian uses as his take-off point the annual Loebner Prize contest in which computers try to convince judges that they are human in competition with some humans who want to convince the judges that THEY are NOT computers! Christian was one of the human competitors in 2009 & uses this experience to engage in a far-ranging exploration of what it means to be human. The subjects he covers are extremely diverse, from the existence of the soul to speed dating, and the sources he cites range from Aristotle to Twyla Tharp to Philip K Dick. He is very clearly smart & very liberally educated, and the result is informative & interesting.At the same time, Christian's writing is quite uneven, at times almost amateurish when he descends into GenX jargon and phrases like " a computer poet would be much scarier of a prospect...". He also seems to pronounce pure personal opinions, with no apparent supporting evidence, as confidently as he quotes renowned authorities & the great thinkers of history. And personally I am not nearly as interested in chess as Christian, even though I admit it has been a focus of a lot of AI work.Nonetheless, the book is entertaining, thought-provoking, and I guarantee you will learn something. I recommend it.

Great look at the Turing test from the human point of view. Brian looks at AI test not from the standard "how do I create a chatbot to perform well during the test", but rather, "how and why would you be able to convince another human that you were in-fact a human". It is amazing how much of our daily lives are scriptable, and hence copyable by computers/AI. Hopefully nobody falls for those long lost cousin in Nigeria scam emails, but an email that simply says "hey this (as a hyperlink) made me think of you -name" would still get many clicks, even in super tech-savvy circles. Another example is highlighted in his explanation about how our society (people) are becoming more robotic (human robots) and it is these jobs that are being replaced by automation; as technology moves forward people need to adapt and fight against complacency.The book is filled with interesting history, philosophy and introductory computer science/AI factoids. Many interesting references are cited and it is clearly written from someone outside the AI community, which is nice because it brings more breadth than other writings that I've read on the Turing Test. The story telling and goal-driven approach to winning The Most Human Human Award worked quite well for the task at hand.I'd suggest it for those interested in the future of computers and humans (hopefully that covers all the readers of this blurb!), as the two will become ever-more tangled in the years to come...

From Publishers WeeklyIn a fast-paced, witty, and thoroughly winning style, Christian documents his experience in the 2009 Turing Test, a competition in which judges engage in five-minute instant-message conversations with unidentified partners, and must then decide whether each interlocutor was a human or a machine. The program receiving the most "human" votes is dubbed the "most human computer," while the person receiving the most votes earns the title of "most human human." Poet and science writer Christian sets out to win the latter title and through his quest, investigates the nature of human interactions, the meaning of language, and the essence of what sets us apart from machines that can process information far faster than we can. Ranging from philosophy through the construction of pickup lines to poetry, Christian examines what it means to be human and how we interact with one another, and with computers as equals—via automated telephone menus and within the medical establishment, for example. This fabulous book demonstrates that we are capable of experiencing and sharing far deeper thoughts than even the best computers—and that too often we fail to achieve the highest level of humanness. This is a challenging, thought provoking book. I enjoyed the discussions of chess, computers, language, and communication.

I liked the premise of the book, but Christian did not spend nearly enough time for me on chatbots, language generation technology, and AI as it is in the world today. I enjoyed the sections on those topics and chess, but honestly way too much of this book was random asides and tangents on things that were mildly relevant and poorly held together. This isn't to mention that the writing was just kind of bad, too. Was there an editor?? As a linguist and academically-minded person I was annoyed by a lot of Christian's broad generalizations. First of all, he has a lot of weird misunderstandings about linguistics and language use. Second of all he seems to think he came up with the field of pragmatics when in fact it is a totally legitimate field (he said something about how linguists haven't thought about issues like "non-words" such as "uhh/umm" in speech, but linguists totally have and write about it a lot). For me this ruined a lot of his other ruminations because I wondered "if he doesn't understand linguistics, does he really understand all these other topics?"All that said, it was an engaging book. And I really did enjoy the parts about chatbots. That was my main reason for reading it, because I think the chatbot world is very interesting, but I think this particular story would be better suited to an hour-long podcast or a longform article than a book.

Well... first I bought it as a Christmas gift for my dad, thinking it would have that nice mix of tech and philosophy that he usually enjoys. Then, during the holidays I end up snatching it, and swallowed the first 3 chapters before realising (as always) that I'd have to choose between reading and being social. So, I had to buy another copy when I got home. And now that I've finished it, my husband will be reading it. To me, this isn't just another book about the history of chess/computer science/... which is sort of what I expected. It's a lovely little gem about not just what makes us human (such an excellent species ;-)) but about that part of our behavior that certainly isn't human at all and yet somehow seems to fill up a lot of our daily lives. It is a gentle reminder to reflect a little more on how to live our lives - living rather than merely existing...One could argue in spirit of this book that just as a philosopher would find it comforting to define thinking as the purpose of humans, a poet would find that purpose strongly linked to language and communication... but then the Turing-test itself has its obvious limits. I'll warmly recommend this book to all of my friends - not just programmers and geeks, but also to people who aren't really that much into tech stuff but have an interest in philosophy and/or linguistics in some way. Enjoy! :-)

What's truly distinctive about us? Author Brian Christian was intrigued by the "most human computer" contest spawned by computer pioneer Alan Turing's famous prediction: by 2000, human simulations would be so convincing that someone chatting online with a human and a bot wouldn't be able to tell them apart. The annual Turing competition (now the Loebner Prize) pairs 4 fake humans (bots) with 4 actual humans. After each 5-minute pair of chats, a judge votes which is which. The bot that convinces the most judges it's human wins the Most Human Computer award. The human that gets the most votes wins the Most Human Human award. How can someone vie to be "most" human? "Just be yourself," Christian was advised. But doesn't that imply it's possible to NOT be yourself?--to fail at being yourself? His yellow brick road toward the Most Human Human award is as adventure-filled as Dorothy's. (Comparisons to "Pilgrim's Progress" are tempting but off the mark.) Christian explores dozens of angles on defining human uniqueness. Along the way we look into definitions of the soul from ancient Greece to Descartes; communication within as well as between brains; contrasting approaches to programming bots; and a host of other factors that make human beings distinctive...if, indeed, we are distinctive!I found this book so rich, diverse, and insightful that I read it twice. Highly recommended!

The history and implications of the Turing test with a focus on its current incarnation as the Loebner Prize is certainly a door to a vast number of AI topics -- amongst others -- that can be immensely interesting. The Most Human Human takes on a number of these topics, trying to rein them in and make them into a cohesive whole. The breadth and variety of topics that the book takes on is enormous. The things that various brain disorders tell us about how our brains work, the progression of human endeavor in philosophical discussion, and the evolution of computer AI, are just a few of the intriguing realms of ideas explored. One of my favorite sections includes an analysis of how lossy and lossless compression work and how they relate to how we interpret the world naturally. The drawback to the expansiveness of the topic is that at times the book really does seem to fail to hold together and more be a series of tangents that don't always come full circle. The book is good and fun and insightful, but for all its attempts to try and setup a methodical order or unified thesis, it seems to come up short. I'd also recommend reading the book as opposed to listening to the audiobook, as the version read by the author is a bit monotone and as it moves through the plethora of facts, you're more likely to miss something than if you have the text in front of you.

Resting on its most basic framework--that the Turing Test and human-computer conversations can inform more about our own language and interpersonal communication--this book absolutely succeeds. One can learn a lot about how different programs approach conversation, how they sometimes succeed, and what the future of computer communication needs to be more human-like. Even more, the discussions of "getting out of book", holds, communication entropy, and the Shannon game were interesting and educational. As others have noted, though, Christian often oversteps his bounds. The book reads like an information dump that feels haphazardly put together to tell a coherent story. Anything that has a remote resemblance to, and that can be fit under a umbrella of computer language and human interaction, is somehow deserving of exposition. It just reads too disconnected, with discussions of compression too tangential to the central thesis, and the essay about how autocorrect forces our language into the vocabulary that Apple/Droid want us to have, itself seems too forced. In 200 (rather than 270) pages, Christian could have told a much tighter and persuasive story. However, and what perhaps is the ultimate metric of non-fiction, I came out the other end of the book more educated than where I started. So for that, 3.5 stars.

Anything interesting Mr. Christian has to say in his book is lost in the frankly sloppy, unfocused and disjointed writing. It's a deep shame, because the topic has the potential to be interesting. I was immediately put off by the author's florid prose - don't get me wrong, I love a bit of extravagant writing now and again, but it was just too much, too often. Nearly every sentence features multiple comma splices. There's a lot of "Indeed, one might say, perhaps, it's well known..." type phrases peppered in that don't do much other than pad out the word count. And - my own personal cardinal sin of writing - the abundance of completely unnecessary italics, just stuffed onto any old word regardless of if its presence improves the sentence. Trust me, once you start noticing unnecessary italics, you'll see them everywhere.I'm sorry, Mr. Christian, I really wanted to like your book. But this is a great example of style over substance where the style wasn't nearly well-done enough to conceal the weak substance.

A curious read for sure. the author has penned his experience with the Leobner prize competition for assessing "turing quality" of machines and in the process evaluating a human to be representative of humanness. The book is an interesting read, chalk full of interesting quotes and references, along with author's own assessment of aspects that make us human. However, I also found the book to be quite obtuse on multiple occassions, finding myself questioning - "okay, interesting information but what is the point?". I am also not a big fan of books whose content promarily comprises of quoting work of others. This book is no exception. It is as if the author feels that without support from other authors, this book would have no bones to stand on its own, would end up being a lump of undifferentiated mass of flesh instead. I don't think this would have been the case. The author had many beautiful insights to share, which would have been delightful to read in their own light and details.

The Most Human Human is a record of Brian Christian's experiences in his quest for the prize of the interlocutor voted to be the human most times in the 2009 Turing Test. He thoroughly explores a deeper question of what our philosophical, biological, neurological, moral, linguistic traits are that set us apart from our artificial counterparts. He talks about the analogies between instances in our daily life and compression (information theory), the repetitive nature of pick-up lines, poetry, the 'singularity', Gary Kasparov's match against Deep Blue and lists down excerpts from his conversations with people pre and post-Turing Test. He has a unique style of writing and the overall take on the problem is different from anything I've read in recent times that's related to AI. Although it gets a tad boring in a (few) parts, there were enough gems to keep me interested till the end. Some parts were so well-worded that I went back and read them again, several times.

The Most Human Human (2012) by Brian Christian looks at how AI can make us reflect on what our human qualities are and how AI relates to them. Christian was one of the human participants in the 2009 Turing Test, where computers attempt to pass as humans as both chat to judges over written messages. Christian has degrees in Computer Science and Philosophy and so is ideally placed to write about the subject of humanity and AI. The book is also well crafted. The story of Christian being a confederate in the Turing Test and his discussion of AI and humanity is interleaved skillfully. Comparing chatbots and how people also follow scripts as well as how computers have improved at chess and other fields and pondering what makes humans different is definitely an interesting topic and the book does this all well.For anyone interested and how humanity is different and similar it's definitely worth a read.

This book about Turing test is a cross-disciplinary analysis of this well-known annual AI event. Author Brian is from a mixed background of poetry, computer science and philosophy, which is rare and probably the main reason why the book is not like a usual AI book you would encounter. Contrary to what the term AI might hint, this non-fiction book is interesting to read. It has quite some insightful threads and let me well informed of Turing test. The quoted transcripts from the actual tests are quite enlightening. One could be more appreciative of his/her fellow humans after reading the human-computer interaction examples in the book.The author rambled a bit and veered off the topic in a few chapters. This didn't hurt my overall understanding, but it did make the author fail to sum up the his points in these chapters. For this reason, I wanted to give 3.5 stars instead of a solid 4.

This is the author's musing about the process he went through to win the title of "Most Human Human" at a Loebner Prize competition for the Turing test. Perhaps I am too knowledgeable about this area, but I found almost nothing new or insightful in this book.I was trying to think one of new thing I learned from the book: it that the space was introduced as an interword separator by Irish monks in the seventh century. (See page 245.) This is apparently true, but the author also makes it sound like there were no interword separators before the 7th century, and in spite of script continua and other languages with no interword space, this is not true: Namely, there are many other kinds of interword separators used in ancient writing, e.g., the interpunct dot in Latin.I would have liked a book that delved deeper into topics, but this one is too superficial.

This is an interesting one. Judging by the cover and text on it you might think it is about what robots are able to do or a story with plottwists about an AI. Neither of them is true. It's mostly about what makes us human, unique, and how to use that by building robots. And that is interesting. If we want to built artificial intelligence that passes Turing tests and works well, we need to understand who we are.Brian Christian has a brilliant mind, is a good observer and seemes programmed to give us all this information.I was excited reading this book, though I have to say it contains lot of (side) information and backgrounds, which slows the book down and makes it pretty incoherent sometimes. It's as far from a relaxing novel as it is from science-fiction. By that I mean that you have to pay full attention during reading.At last, aren't we robots in some way?

Brian Christian has the perfect background to approach the topic of artificial intelligence: he has degrees in philosophy, poetry, and computer science. He understands information theory (and does a great job of breaking it down for the layman), but treats the whole topic within the context of the question: what does it mean to be human?I love his informal style of writing, as well as the rabbit-trails of delightfully interesting concepts, which always resolve into profound insights about being human. He perfectly blends his own anecdotes (chiefly about participating in the Loebner competition- a contest in which both computers and humans try to convince judges they are human)with the main arguments and conclusions of the book.

This book is all over the place, roaming through philosophy and computer science, art and mathematics, with the Turing test as the reason for looking into just what it is that makes us human when faced with increasingly "intelligent" machines. At times the digressions seemed not to go far enough, and other times they seemed to go on and on, and in the end, I think the book is useful as a kind of thought primer- let your brain, with its amazing ability to associate different ideas, continue where Christian cuts his explorations off. Despite (and because of) this rambling nature, I really enjoyed this book, and the opportunity it gave me to think about being human, language, art, and, of course, computers.

I loved this book because it addressed so many areas that interest me: technology, ethics, humanity, philosophy, poetry...I found this book incredibly interesting and resonant for me. Additionally, I should mention that Christian tackled a lot of tough concepts with admirable grace and clarity, explaining very complicated ideas around computer programming and the like very simply and assuming no prior knowledge. The footnotes are hilarious.Christian's voice is witty, fun, smart, and personal. There is nothing at all boring about this book. And that's saying something--he managed to make computer talk fun!This book is brilliant. It's fun. It's possibly the most thought-provoking book I have ever read. And it is very very smart.

The premise of this book sounded awesome. I've since heard that This American Life and Radiolab did stories jumping off from this book and I feel safe to assume I'd probably enjoy those more than I did reading this book. First, Christian left out his participation in the actual event that was driving this book. That, to me, was the essence of this narrative - and it never made an appearance. There were some great bits in here about chatbots and language. But, geez, some of these tangential ideas turned into massive detours. I left really confused and lost at points trying to figure out exactly what Christian wanted this book to be. That confusion aside, though, there are some interesting bits.

One of the most enjoyable nonfiction books I've read in a long time. Brian Christian is a poet as well as a computer programmer, and both sensibilities inform this book. Christian uses his experience serving as one of the human "controls" at the big annual Turing Test as the jumping-off point for a clearly and warmly written popsci survey of various topics in cognitive science, linguistics, information theory, and AI research. Lots of clever lines, lots of great quotes, lots of subtle and overt encouragements to the reader to be more the kind of person I also want more people to be: curious, idiosyncratic, novelty-preferring, dissatisfied with confining, predictable roles and language. I find Christian to be a kindred spirit -- I liked his book, and after reading it I liked him.

Computers are becoming faster, and better programmed, so that one day they might be able to “think” like human beings. In fact, at a 2008 software competition, a computer program called Elbot deceptively convinced almost 30% of judges interrogating it via teleprompter that they were exchanging messages with another human being – and for this, Elbot won the “Most Human Computer” award. At that same competition, a “Most Human Human” award went to the human contestant who was able to convince the most number of judges that they were indeed teletyping exchanges with another human being. As computers deepen their ability to talk and interact like humans with humans, the book explores the question -what is it that makes our conversations with each other human?

Once a year, a bunch of people get together to judge a bunch of chatterbots on their ability to pass the Turing test. The judges talk a mix of bots and real people and try to figure out who is who. One of the awards handed out is for the "Most Human Human"—the person who was most easily identifiable as a human being based on their chats. Christian sets out to win that prize in 2009, and the result is this thought provoking book about the way we reason, the way we communicate and the complexities of language.The book is a few years old so some of the bots he praises seem quite poor, but that's really secondary to the more interesting philosophical discussion to be had here (as well as a nice little anecdote around why those who think philosophy is useless are already philosophizing).

Every once in a while I decide to recommend a book before I finish it, this is always a mistake. The book was good, but moments of it were truly great. It is one man's quest to decide what makes conversation human and how much could be replaced by computers. I think there were moments that the author got lost in his own ideas or pursuit of an idea, but there were definite lessons that I will take away that might improve my communication skills. The idea that we are so easily replaced by a machine in something so personal as conversation frightens me much more than the thought that a robot could take my job. The author gets credit for being one of very few whose writing made me stop reading and pick up pen and paper and take notes and write reflections.

Hm. I don't read much non-fiction, with the exception of textbooks and histories. Histories tend to be written in a very linear style; textbooks not as much so. Perhaps it was that unfortunate association that turned me off from the book. The writing itself is gently humorous and absorbing, but there was only a very lose narrative flow. I kept waiting for him to get to the competition itself, but it only showed up in snippets here and there. Which is perfectly right, as it wasn't the basis or purpose of his book. But I think for me, I would have found that just as interesting as the philosophy.

A thoughtful and lively book about the humanistic elements of communication that make possible and detract from living a life with others. Although the quick jump between examples and analogies became a little annoying, Christian is able to distill some of the more interesting aspects of human communication and make them available to a wide audience. If you're interested in the more theoretical implications of his quest, I suggest John Durham Peters' Speaking into the Air: A History of the Idea of Communication.

This book is, in many ways, right up my alley - about AI, linguistics, etc. I probably enjoyed it more than a three. I found much of the discussion of intelligence - both human and machine - to be interesting. I also found that, like many pop-science books, more time was spent illustrating each point than was necessary. This makes the book drag after a while. I was disappointed not to be able to read more of the actual transcripts of the Turing test that resulted in the Most Human Human award. Generally, i think the book could have been more focused. Still, it is an easy read, and enjoyable in most respects.

This book was a fascinating look at the evolution of AI and how machines are making us question exactly what it means to be human. The advances made in computer technology within the last century have caused us to rethink what for ages philosophers have suggested: that Reason is what separates man from beast...what makes us distinctly human. Throughout the book Brian Christian describes his preparation for the 2009 Turing Test and his quest to prove his humanity. Although the book had its slow parts, the topics are intriguing and the book ventures into a deep exploration of human language and cognition. Definitely worth a read.

Got this advice from a friend, starting to read it...Seems interesting in concept. Can a machine be more human than a "real" human ?-Wow! Started out very interesting, but now its heading to a detailed analytical discourse that has me lost. Still interesting, but demanding too much brain power and attention, not so light anymore...-Finished!A book about so many topics (almost all computer/tech related) that are seemingly disconnected, yet all touch base with the subject of human comunication and evolution. Very interesting!Read this in PDF but it merits buying and re-reading the book in paper to try and get more "juice".

This is the most interesting book I've read since Godel, Escher, Bach, although it's shorter and written on a much more general levelThe basic premise is that the author is trying to win the "most human human" award at the Turing test. So he researches the ways in which humans are different from computers and ways humans communicate that computers would have trouble with.It delves into a broad range of topics relating to linguistics, AI, and philosophy... basically cognitive science.I guess my one complaint is the way the notes are arranged in the back... I wish there was just a Bibliography I could look at because then my "further reading" would be easier to compile.

currently enjoying this very much, though I wish it was a bit more structured. Christian wanders through anecdotes, from journal articles and interviews to personal observations and "I read in a book the other day". I appreciate the varied perspective on the topic, which I think particularly suits a book that seeks to examine human intelligence through the lenses of attention, boredom, and wit. And, his overarching themes are made pretty clear. Still, I wish that the flow was more logical- the actual time the author spends at the Loebner prize competition is so broken up between chapters that I feel like I lost this part of the story. Will update more once I finish.

In this thought provoking, pleasantly meandering non-fiction narrative, Brian Christian explores one big question: Is there a difference in the way that humans and computers communicate and process information?. As a confederate in a yearly Turing test experiment, Christian's goal is to win the "The Most Human Human" prize at the 2009 Loebner competition. The author uses his back ground in computer science, philosophy, and poetry to create an intriguing set of logical points that touch on biology, sociology, chess, cybernetics, and much, much more. This is easily one of the best books that I've ever read.

Using his participation in the annual Turing Test competition as a platform, the author touches on several topics ranging from philosophy to data processing in order to get at what it really means to communicate like a human, and how that separates us from computers (or in some ways, makes us eerily similar).This book is like most other layperson's guide to X field in that there is probably some hand-waving of detail as well as fanciful speculation, but it is a good read. The author brings up some very interesting ideas and does it in an accessible way. I guarantee that after reading this, you will strive harder for meaningful conversation, if only to be not mistaken for a bot online.

An interesting read given the recent disastrous experiment of Microsoft's Tay bot and the announcement of Facebook's Messenger bot integration. Artificial intelligence is becoming more mainstream (through corporate experimentation) but has the science gone astray in attempting to develop a more 'human' robot? What does it mean to be human anyways? These are some of the questions the author delves into with considerable depth throughout the book. The reader can get lost in the theories discussed and the philosophy behind what it means to be human. Otherwise, it is an interesting exploration of the topic.

I just read some excerpts from this book that got me interested:"Who would have imagined that the computer's earliest achievements would be in the domain of logical analysis, a capacity held to be what made us most different from everything on the planet? That it could drive a car and guide a missile before it could ride a bike? That it could make plausible preludes in the style of Bach before it could make plausible small talk? That it could translate before it could paraphrase? That it could spin half-plausible postmodern theory essays* before it could be shown a chair and say, as any toddler can, "

"The Most Human Human" was more a philosophy text than a computer-science or even computer-interaction text, and the structure of Christian's story proved to be something of an obstacle to enjoyment. Despite the lack of a clear theme or progress along a through-line (as well as the lack of any significant details of his performance in the Loebner Prize Turing Test), there were some interesting insights into the nature of intra-human communication sprinkled throughout.Side note: The second "what" in the book's subtitle drives me so crazy. Couldn't he have sent that through one more round of editing to expunge it?

While reading this book I found myself often stopping to ponder and reflect. Just how do human beings fit into the scheme of life? That the author has at least three major interests is evident – philosophy, poetry and computer science. He participated in the 2009 Turing test, which matches computer programs against human beings. Objective was to see if judges could mistake computer programs for actual humans. Book delineates thought processes author underwent in order to outwit computer. He interweaves his major interests and more. There’s existentialism, entropy, chess, logic, robot, Plato, Aristotle, on and on. Foods for thought and reflection, overall, of what it means to be human.

I found the premise of this book (the author is a human control in a contest called the Touring Test which tests the human-ness of both artificial Intelligence programs, and it turns out humans) to be intriguing all on it's own. As the author prepares for the other award of this test, The Most Human Human award, he travels through philosophy, computer science, information theory and our modern experiences with computing and technology. I listened to the book, which is read by the author, and found the flow very pleasing and conversational. Also because the book must ultimately get back to the results of the test, it has a narrative arc very much like a novel.

This book explores so many different perspectives of humanity and what it is to be unique. To think freely is to draw upon experiences and data that have been a part of the world in which we all exist, so can we ever have a truly free and unique thought? Gah, one could spend a lifetime contemplating whether or not we as humans are so great that we cannot be exactly replicated or replaced. For the record, I don't know exactly where I stand on the afterlife, or capital G God, or hell, or prayer, but I do believe, if not wholly, in the concepts depicted in the movie 'I Robot'I don't know what that says about me, but this book made me reflect on it.

This is a book about the Turing Test, where computers compete for the Most Human Computer Award, trying to convince judges they are not a computer. To do this, they have to also include humans--referred to as confederates--in the competition. The humans all compete for the Most Human Human Award. As Brian Christian talks about his experience being a confederate in 2009, he brings up many interesting points that arise from a competition like this. Aspects of Philosophy, Humanism, Identity, Communication, and Language are discussed throughout this book, all trying to answer the question of "what does it means to be human?".

The author hears about the Loebner Prize (a Turing test competition) and gets himself listed as a "confederate", which is a person who is used, along with an AI program, to "talk" with judges, who then decide which is which. They have a "most human computer" and a "most human human" award, and he's gunning for the latter. Why don't they have a "most robotic" human and computer awards? I'd like to do this and respond with "I'm a robot" to all queries and/or write a program that does the same, just to see what happens. He goes through a lot of thinking about thought, intelligence, etc. It's a fun book if you're a geek.

Brian, the author of the book, decides to compete in Loebner prize, another award given in Turing test, basically human who was most convincingly human while chatting to a judge on computer screen. As he prepares for the test, he explores the idiosyncrasies in language and what does it mean to human. The book is peppered with excerpts about information theory, compression algorithms, entropy and computer graphics. While he is at it, he also tries to demystify what goes behind building chatbots and chess-winning computer programs, and what are those uniquely human things which are very hard for a computer to simulate in a conversation.

The story of competing as a "human" in the 2009 Loebner Prize competition, the current Turing test. A linguist, computer programmer, and poet explains what makes language interesting, what makes life surprising, and yeah, what it means to be human. Blah blah blah. It's better than the blurbs make it sound.Basically this is targeted straight into my brain-stem. Not much of the total package was new to me, but the style was refreshing and the new perspectives that he brings are either awesome, hilarious, or both.P.S. WHAT IS THOUGHT??

There were several moments of insight, but at times the author was trying too hard to be esoteric. I think I got the main ideas... but a lot of the time I was just trying to hang on to the thread of the narrative. Anyone who has read The Information: A History, a Theory, a Flood could probably skip this (many of the most interesting anecdotes are shared between the two books).

I was willing to love this book, I was waiting to love this book, I was wanting to love this book, but instead... I had to work really hard to slog all the way through it, right to the end, slog, slog, slog. It took me months, MONTHS!It is such an interesting topic and I came prepared to be fascinated. I really wanted to adore the book and I couldn't and that makes me sad. It's not that it was bad, you understand. It wasn't bad at all, I just didn't love it; it wasn't compelling in any way, and given the topic?  disappoint

I found this book to be really cute and quite fundamental to an understanding of the limits of modern computation. It spends a lot of time describing chess algorithms, information theory, and Turing test issue.In general it comes across as a very thoughtful and personal analysis of how we can define ourselves as humans. About ideal dinner conversation or salon conversation, though obviously not technical enough for job interviews.I did find the section on information theory to be a bit detached from the rest of it, though this is a minor flaw.

I have to agree with the review that said this was poorly written. There are places where and really drags a bit. That said I thought the topics covered and examples were fantastic. The whole idea of human communication being analogous to the opening book, middle game, and in the endgame in chess is fascinating and for me was illuminating. I thought it really dove deeply into what it means to be human, and the nature of human communication. I highly recommend the book, even if the writing could be tightened up.
